citation.article-title: Cucumibacter marinus gen. nov., sp. nov., a marine bacterium in the family Hyphomicrobiaceae
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Cucumibacter marinus sp. nov.
Cucumibacter marinus (ma.ri′nus. L. masc. adj. marinus referring to the sea, from where the type strain was isolated).
Displays the following properties in addition to those given in the genus description.
After 7 days on MA plates at 35 °C, colonies are circular, convex, creamy and approximately 0.8 mm in diameter.
Cells are approximately 0.4–0.6 μm wide and 1.5–2.0 μm long.
Growth occurs at sea salts concentrations of 1–10 % (w/v) (optimum, 3–4 %) and at NaCl concentrations of 1–3 % (optimum, 2 %).
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.

With the API ZYM system, positive for alkaline and acid phosphatases, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), β-galactosidase, β-glucosidase, leucine arylamidase, lipase (C14) and naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, but negative for α-chymotrypsin, cystine arylamidase, α-fucosidase, α-galactosidase, α-glucosidase, β-glucuronidase, α-mannosidase, N-acetyl-β-glucosaminidase, trypsin and valine arylamidase.

Utilizes l-arabinose, l-arginine, l-asparagine, betaine, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, glutamic acid, glycerol, lactose, d- and l-leucine, d-mannitol, mannose, pyruvate, sucrose and trehalose as sole carbon sources, but not dl-cysteine, dimethyl sulfide, glycine, p-hydroxyphenylacetate, maleic acid, succinate or urea.

Cells are sensitive to (μg per disc) ampicillin (10), cephalexin (30), chloramphenicol (30), erythromycin (15), penicillin G (10) and vancomycin (30) but resistant to gentamicin (10), nalidixic acid (30) and streptomycin (10).
The DNA G+C content is 62.9 mol%.

In addition to the polar lipids listed in the genus description, minor or trace amounts of phosphatidylcholine, phosphatidylethanolamine, an unidentified phospholipid, an unidentified aminophospholipid and three unidentified lipids can be detected.
The type strain, CL-GR60T (=KCCM 90027T =DSM 18995T), was isolated from coastal seawater from the East Sea, Korea.
